author: 8BrickMario
title: The Enrichment Center must inform you that monetary contribution is a requirement for progress.
review:
One of the biggest surprises of LEGO Dimensions is that Portal would join its list of franchises. Does the game do it justice? 

Box/Instructions

The Dimensions sets have a unique trapezoidal package with an inverted trapezoid for the backing, which includes the shelf hook. This allows two same-sized packs to be stacked upside-down while taking up the same amount of space. The instructions are rudimentary, telling you how to assemble Chell only. 

Parts

There are some very nice parts here, with the most notable being the portal gun. The piece is cast out of rubber to keep it from breaking, but its material makes it incrediby difficult to put in Chell's hand, and it cannot be rotated once it is. It neatly fits a simulated light piece in the end, which can be switched out for an orange one depending on which portal she's shooting. Another nice piece I've wanted for a while is a solitary heart crystal, more common in the minidoll themes. 

Minifigures

Chell is a very nice figure. I'm not sure her hair is a very good choice, as it's combed differently and longer in the back, but it's alright. Her face accurately represents her default stoic expression, and her alternate face shows her angered or annoyed, perhaps by Wheatley, as seen in-game. Her torso is nicely printed with her Aperture Science top, and her legs continue the uniform with the dual-molded technique showing orange shorts and white boots. 

The build

The builds were pretty easy, due to their size. 

The completed model

The builds in this pack are pretty nice. First is the famous Weighted Companion Cube. The base for the cube includes mainly filler parts used in the upgraded models, but the cube itself is nice, despite the inability to make it a perfect cube shape. The five sides with the recognizable heart design are printed. Interestingly, the top of the cube with two of the sides can come off fairly easily, due to using a jumper tile to keep it on. I haven't rebuilt it, so I don't know if the jumper is more important in the later models. 

The other model is the Sentry Turret, one of many hazards in Aperture Science. It manages to look exactly like a turret from the game without too many pieces. However, its back leg is rather poor and would be better represented by another one of the front legs. 

Gameplay

In-game, Chell is a bit specialized, being the only one who can create portals on designated panels. She is also acrobatic, but while I enjoy her inclusion, you'll only really need her for portal creation. Her Companion Cube retains its purpose of weighing down certain switches. It can be used by anyone; most will carry it, looking like they're hurting their back, but Chell will levitate it with her portal gun, just like in the original games. The Turret is useful for the primary reason of activating turret switches, which require the rapid-fire blasts of the turret to keep working. 

The Portal 2 level itself is a lot of fun. Almost all of the puzzles involve classic Portal game mechanics, such as switches, gels, the Companion Cube, and of course, the titular portals. The story is pretty basic, with Chell and co. (omitted from cutscenes) traveling through Aperture to get to GLaDOS, while accompanied by Wheatley. The humor is a blend of GLaDOS' trademark sarcasm and LEGO's traditional silliness, and the amount of references packed into the level is great. The Aperture Science world is also pretty fun, though perhaps a bit tricky to navigate, and in true Aperture fashion, it tests every ability in the game, requiring several characters to solve all of the "tests". 

Overall opinion

I think this is probably the best level pack in the game so far. It introduces a new franchise that works surprisingly well with LEGO, and the gameplay provided is very enjoyable.  I would definitely recommend this to anyone who plays Dimensions and especially to the Portal fans who do so.

author: GBP_Chris
title: Cave Johnson would have fired someone over this atrocity
review:
I'm a longtime Portal fan. Played Portal and Portal 2, Aperture Tag, and am working through Portal Stories and Half-Life. I'm also a longtime Lego fan, never had a dark age and spent my days MOCing and brickfilming. So when I found my two favorite things were going to combine into one, I was ecstatic! A Lego Chell? A Lego Portal gun?

Ladies and gentlemen, this set is atrocious. I almost regret buying it except for the fact that I never return Lego sets.

Box/Instructions

I understand this is part of a game, but I don't appreciate the lack of instructions for the turret and cube in the box. Had to look these up separately online.

Parts

The parts assortment is way too small for a USD $30.00 set. At a measly 85 pieces, there are a few highlights. A lot of helpful white slopes and some rarities - transparent blue shields, black short sticks, even the printed tiles of the Companion Cube are nice. The portal gun, however, is a flimsy rubber piece I fear will suffer abrasion if even touched.

For those who ever bought a Lego Agents set and watched as Dr. Inferno's hairpiece lost the orange texture on the rubber, I would like you to apply that fear to the white texture on the portal gun.

Minifigures

Chell is a decent minifigure, but I would have appreciated some kind of piece to represent her Aperture jacket wrapped around her waist. That, and her face just doesn't seem to match the game much - it's too angry and annoyed. Chell in Portal and Portal 2 has more of a neutral expression that just doesn't come across here.

Her stand is cool - I like the Aperture logo.

The completed model

The Companion Cube is awful. Such a terribly built cube - the Lego dice from the Lego Games line would have made a better substitute for the awful array of plates and tiles used to construct this abomination. It resembles the in-game item but has about as much thought put into it as 75098 Assault on Hoth. Yeah, it's that bad.

The Turret remains a joke between my friend and I to this day. It is ridiculously oversized and looks like GLaDOS tried to implement a new inflatable turret design. For those who have not played the game, a turret is the size of a normal human being and a lot slimmer. It resembles a turret, but to say anything more would be a disgrace to Cave Johnson's good name.

I have not played the game as I do not have Lego Dimensions, so I will restrict this review to the set. That is why I bought it - to have some kind of Portal Lego representation.

Overall opinion

Am I being too harsh? My aforementioned friend likewise bought the Back To The Future pack, which he displays prominently next to his Ideas DeLorean. Those models are beautiful and very well represent the elements from the movie. Plus, they allow for people without the Dimensions game to appreciate the models.

This Portal pack, however, deserves a trip down the incinerator.

The models are hideous, the price is atrocious, the pieces have their own problems, and I have no doubt that Cave Johnson is rolling in his grave over this right now. Perhaps Lego will be able to rectify the situation and make a better Portal set of some sort. For the people who are still alive ...

author: Odeinoichus
title: Aperture Science Expansion Pack.
review:
Set #71203 Portal 2: The third Level Pack from Series 1 of LEGO Dimensions is based on a highly popular video game franchise, one which I have had no prior exposure to, which isn’t that big of a deal because even if you don’t know much about it the Digital Content with this set in the Game will explain everything. Or nothing at all, it’s highly subjective. This set has some very decent looking models.

Packaging

This is Level Pack packaging, which I have discussed in greater detail in The LEGO Dimensions Back to the Future Level Pack review. Uniform packaging across the entire Theme is even more straightforward than regular LEGO themes.

Parts

Printed elements are included for the Companion Cube’s five visible sides. It also includes a brand new Minifigure accessory element for the Portal Gun used by Chell, the rest of the parts are pretty common.

Minifigures

Chell: Representing the main Protagonist of the Portal franchise, Chell looks quite nice in a Minifigure form. Her legs are dual-molded so she’s got white boots and an upper orange pair of pants. She has a dual-sided torso with the Aperture logo on the front and bare arms, her head is also dual-sided featuring a neutral expression and an open mouth angry expression and her hair piece is dark brown.

Her toy tag looks quite nice and her accessory is very well done, a great looking Portal gun. A shame it hasn’t been re-used in any official sets.

The build

Sentry Turret: I enjoyed this build considerably, it creates a very accurate looking model with a diverse use of parts. I literally don’t know much about the Portal games, but this model is a really fun build and probably looks like an actual sentry turret from the official games in LEGO form.

Turret Striker: I’m not a fan of this model, the build for it is just a bit lazy since you’re pretty much building the normal turret, but then swapping parts around to make it look like a goofy looking robot drone with arms. Not functional arms mind you, but the profile of the model as you build it really looks odd and takes up too much space when you attach it to the base.

Flying Turret Carrier: This build is equally silly, I don’t mind it as much as the second model, but this build doesn’t offer up much. It’s the only version of the model that can incorporate a Minifigure though as studs are now visible on the front when you’re building, which can act as a sort of seat.

Companion Cube: You’re building a cube, the bottom of the stand includes more elements to accommodate the 3-1 build, but ultimately you’re just building a square shape. It does use some nice SNOT techniques though, so there is that.

Laser Deflector: It’s almost the exact same build as the first model, you simply change up where the extra parts found on the base go and instead they are facing on the side to ‘deflect’ lasers. Pretty much a simple build.

Gold Heart Emitter: This build is the least fun looking once finished, but I do admit the build itself is interesting looking as you work through the steps to transform a cube shape into a heart dispensing cube.

The completed model

Sentry Turret Models: The models involved with this set includes basically the same basic body construction, the Sentry Turret is the most compacted with all of the parts integrated quite nicely, the Turret Striker is slightly modified to expand the sides and open it up to mimic more weapons for firing, or at least presumably so, as there are no projectiles here. The Flying Turret Carrier changes the entire design a lot more to expand and allow for Minifigures to actually sit on top. I feel the Sentry Turret and Flying Turret Carrier are the stronger of the two models, both of them are quite strongly put together and both function the best as models. They also look better than the middle form due to the design being better executed. (In my opinion.)

Companion Cube Models: All three variations of the model are pretty similar to one another, just as with the Hoverboard in the Back to the Future Level Pack. The big difference between that model and these is that each of these includes far more pieces and manages to look quite nice in either form. The Companion Cube itself is a square hovering on top of some extra parts, Laser Deflector takes the shield element and incorporates them into the cube design to ‘deflect’ lasers. The final model adds more elements onto the basic cube design and that’s pretty much all there is to say about this trio of models.

The Digital Content

The Level & Adventure World: This is the only pack which can access the Portal Adventure World, or Portal 2 Adventure World if you want to get technical, however the bonus stage is not the only level featuring this setting, the main storyline from the Starter Pack also featured a Portal Level.

The packaging says a Portal 2 Adventure, the level is merely called Aperture Science and it is a juicy meal to sink your teeth into, a relatively long level that should take about a half hour or more to complete 100% as there are many areas to access and explore, and a lot of puzzles to tease the player.

The Adventure World is suitably vast and expansive with a lot to do. To note, there were some glitches to be found in this world at times, as is the case with some of these add-ons. However you can explore it all and the fun dialogue moments for the quests are truly enjoyable and fun to listen to.

Vehicle & Character Abilities: Chell includes a unique ability, she can use her Portal Gun to create portals in key areas of the game, she also has the Acrobat ability allowing her to interact with acrobat puzzles.

The Sentry Turret is a rideable vehicle with no unique abilities, when rebuilt and upgraded into the Turret Striker it can destroy Gold LEGO objects and the third and final upgrade allows it to fly, interacting with Flight Docks and Flight Cargo Hooks to solve flight based puzzles. It can also destroy Silver LEGO objects.

The Companion Cube is used for Portal specific puzzles called Weight Switches in game. Its second form becomes capable of deflecting lasers and the final form lets you solve weight puzzles and also heal hearts when your character is standing close by.

Overall opinion

The LEGO Portal 2 Level Pack is a necessary item if you want to complete the LEGO Dimensions Game to 200% completion for both Series 1 and Series 2 puzzles, gold bricks and minikits. The buildable models and Chell are very impressive looking and very well designed, fans of the Portal franchise will truly enjoy the many elements found digitally and physically. Compared to the previous two Level Packs I also feel there is a lot of content here that doesn’t suffer any issues, it is one of my favorite levels in the game and I am not even a follower of the Portal franchise. It’s just very cleverly designed and everything is pretty solid.

I strongly recommend getting this set if you’re interested in playing LEGO Dimensions and experiencing everything the title has to offer.
